TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in PERSON . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE , while he was serving a prison term in the PERSON - Šaca prison , the applicant sent an envelope by registered mail . The address on the envelope read as follows :
“ Head of ORG
POST OFFICE
PERSON
GPE CARDINAL “ .

The envelope had registration number R CARDINAL . It contained another envelope . The latter was addressed to the applicant ’s parents and contained a letter which the applicant wanted to be sent to ORG .

The main envelope also contained an accompanying letter for the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office . In the letter the applicant addressed the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office “ Dear Madam ” and requested her to deliver the enclosed envelope to his parents at their expenses . The applicant explained that he was serving a prison sentence and that he could not send letters to certain addresses .

On DATE the applicant ’s registered mail arrived at the PERSON CARDINAL post office which is the main post office in the city . An employee in charge of correspondence addressed to ORG opened the main envelope . After having read the applicant ’s request addressed to the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office , she re - directed the applicant ’s mail , in the original envelope , to the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office which is in charge of delivering mail in DATE where the applicant ’s parents live . The PERSON CARDINAL post office is situated in DATE , but it is not charged with delivering mail to addressees .

The applicant ’s registered letter R CARDINAL arrived at the PERSON CARDINAL post office on DATE . Its head could not comply with the applicant ’s request that the enclosed envelope be delivered to his parents at their expenses as postal regulations require that the postage be paid in advance .
On DATE the applicant was released from prison . He complained to the post that his registered mail had not been delivered .

Following the applicant ’s complaint the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office sent the envelope addressed to the applicant ’s parents back at the applicant ’s address in the PERSON - Šaca prison by ordinary mail in accordance with the relevant regulation . On DATE the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office informed the applicant accordingly .
On DATE the director of the PERSON prison administration informed the applicant that according to the register of ORG mail his registered letter R CARDINAL had not been returned to the prison .

On DATE the head of ORG of ORG informed the applicant that his registered letter had been delivered to the addressee , i.e. the head of the post office concerned , and that he had therefore no right to compensation for its loss . The applicant was further informed that the head of the post office had not been entitled to deliver the enclosed envelope to the applicant ’s parents at their expenses as requested by the applicant since ORG did not provide such a service .

The letter by the head of ORG also stated that the head of the PERSON CARDINAL post office had sent the envelope in question back at the applicant ’s address in the PERSON - Šaca prison by non - registered mail . Since ORG kept no records of the distribution of such mail , it was impossible to establish where the letter had been lost .

On DATE the applicant complained about the interference with his correspondence to ORG ( Ústavný súd ) . On DATE the applicant was requested to submit documentary evidence . He was further informed that in the proceedings before ORG he had to be represented by a lawyer .
On DATE the applicant supplemented his submissions to ORG . He stated that he was indigent and requested that a lawyer be appointed to represent him .

On DATE a judge of ORG requested that the applicant appoint , within DATE , a lawyer representing him in the proceedings . The letter further stated that ORG lacked jurisdiction to appoint a lawyer ex officio .
On DATE the applicant requested ORG that a lawyer be appointed to represent him before ORG . He explained that several lawyers had refused to represent him and that he was indigent .
On DATE the applicant informed ORG that he was detained and that ORG had not yet appointed a lawyer to him .

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s petition . It held that the applicant ’s submissions were not sufficient for proceedings before ORG to be started . The decision stated that the applicant had not been deprived of his liberty throughout the time during which his petition had been prepared for a preliminary examination . In ORG view , the applicant had had enough time to specify , possibly with the assistance of a lawyer , the evidence which he proposed to take and the decision which he sought to obtain .
At the relevant time the indication of addresses on mail was governed by LAW of ORG of DATE ( PERSON o právach a povinnostiach pošty a jej používateľov ) . The relevant provisions read as follows :

Paragraph CARDINAL provides that the address must be indicated accurately with a view to preventing any doubts as to the place and person to whom the mail is to be delivered . Post offices charged with the delivery of mail are authorised to determine whether an address is indicated correctly and accurately .
Pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL , mail with inaccurate or incomplete address shall be returned to the sender .

Paragraph CARDINAL ( a ) provides that address on mail which is to be delivered within the country shall indicate , in the first place , the addressee , i.e. the first name and surname of a person or the name of a company or organisation .
